{{redirect|Hallows|the surname|Hallows (surname)}} {{For|the Worcestershire village|Hallow, Worcestershire}} {{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{wiktionary}}
To '''hallow''' is "to make [[holy]] or sacred, to sanctify or consecrate, to venerate".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/hallow|date=15 January 2007|accessdate=23 January 2007|title=Dictionary.com|publisher=Lexico Publishing Group, LLC.}}</ref> The adjective form ''hallowed'', as used in ''[[Lord's Prayer|The Lord's Prayer]]'', means holy, consecrated, sacred, or revered.<ref>''Webster's Collegiate Dictionary'' entry for ''hallowed''</ref> The noun form ''hallow'', as used in ''[[Hallowtide]]'', is a synonym of the word [[saint]].<ref name="WilsonFischer2005"/><ref name="DiehlDonnelly2001"/><ref name="Leslie1895"/>
==Etymology== {{further|Weoh}} The noun is from the [[Old English]] adjective ''hālig'', nominalised as ''se hālga'' "the holy man". The [[Gothic language|Gothic]] word for "holy" is either ''hailags'' or ''weihaba'', ''weihs''. "To hold as holy" or "to become holy" is ''weihnan'', "to make holy, to sanctify" is ''weihan''. Holiness or sanctification is ''weihiþa''. Old English, like Gothic, had a second term of similar meaning, ''wēoh'' "holy", with a substantive ''wīh'' or ''wīg'', [[Old High German]] ''wīh'' or ''wīhi'' ([[Middle High German]] ''wîhe'', [[German language|Modern German]] ''Weihe''). The [[Nordendorf fibula]] has ''wigiþonar'', interpreted as ''wīgi-þonar'' "holy [[Donar]]" or "sacred to Donar". [[Old Norse]] ''[[Vé (shrine)|vé]]'' is a type of [[shrine]]. The ''weihs'' group is cognate to [[Latin]] ''victima'', an animal dedicated to the gods and destined to be [[animal sacrifice|sacrificed]].
==In current usage== Hallow, as a noun, is a synonym of the word [[saint]].<ref name="WilsonFischer2005">{{cite book|last1=Wilson|first1=Douglas|last2=Fischer|first2=Ty|title=Omnibus II: Church Fathers Through the Reformation|date=30 June 2005|publisher=Veritas Press|isbn=9781932168440|page=101|quote=The word "hallow" means "saint," in that "hallow" is just an alternative form of the word "holy" ("hallowed be Thy name").}}</ref><ref name="DiehlDonnelly2001">{{cite book|last1=Diehl|first1=Daniel|last2=Donnelly|first2=Mark|title=Medieval Celebrations: How to Plan Holidays, Weddings, and Feasts with Recipes, Customs, Costumes, Decorations, Songs, Dances, and Games|date=1 May 2001|publisher=Stackpole Books|isbn=9780811728669|page=13|quote=The word hallow was simply another word for saint.}}</ref> In modern English usage, the noun "hallow" appears mostly in the compound [[Hallowtide]], a liturgical season which includes the days of [[Halloween]] and [[Hallowmas]].<ref name="Leslie1895">{{cite book|last=Leslie|first=Frank|title=Frank Leslie's Popular Monthly|accessdate=3 September 2014|year=1895|publisher=Frank Leslie Publishing House|page=539|work=Allhallowtide|quote=Just as the term "Eastertide" expresses for us the whole of the church services and ancient customs attached to the festival of Easter, from Palm Sunday until Easter Monday, so does All-hallowtide include for us all the various customs, obsolete and still observed, of Halloween, All Saints' and All Souls' Days. From the 31st of October until the morning of the 3d of November, this period of three days, known as All-hallowtide, is full of traditional and legendary lore.}}</ref> Halloween (or ''Hallowe'en'') is a shortened form of "All Hallow Even," meaning "All Hallows' Eve" or "All Saints' Eve."<ref>''Webster's Collegiate Dictionary'' entry for ''Halloween''</ref> Hallowmas, the day after Halloween, is shortened from "Hallows' [[Mass (liturgy)|Mass]]," and is also known as "[[All Saints' Day|All Hallows]]' Day" or "[[All Saints' Day]]."<ref>''Webster's Collegiate Dictionary'' entry for ''Hallowmas''</ref>
==In legend== Some important and powerful objects in legends could be referred to as "hallows" because of their function and symbolism.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mystical-www.co.uk/arthuriana2z/h.htm#HOB|accessdate=16 February 2007|title= Arthurian A-ZZ|publisher=Mystical WWW}}</ref> The [[Tuatha de Danaan]] in Ireland possessed the [[Four Treasures of the Tuatha Dé Danann|Four Treasures]] of Ireland which could be interpreted as "hallows": the [[Lugh#Lug.27s Spear|Spear of Lugh]], [[Lia Fáil|Stone of Fal]], the [[Claíomh Solais|Sword of Light]] of [[Nuada]], and [[The Dagda]]'s [[Dagda's Cauldron|Cauldron]].
In the modern period, some neo-pagans believe that the four suits in the [[Rider-Waite tarot deck|Rider-Waite]] [[Tarot|Tarot cards]] deck (swords, wands, pentacles and cups), which are also a representation of the four [[classical elements]] of air, fire, earth and water, are also hallows.
[[Coronation]] ceremonies for monarchs still invokes four ritual objects, now represented as the [[sceptre]], [[sword]], [[ampulla]] of oil, and [[Crown (headgear)|crown]]. Similar objects also appear in [[King Arthur|Arthurian]] legends, where the [[Fisher King]] is the guardian of four "hallows" representing the four elements: a dish (earth), Arthur's sword [[Excalibur]] (air), the [[Holy Lance]] or spear, baton, or a magic wand (fire), and the [[Holy Grail]] (water).<ref name=Fisher_king>{{cite web|url=http://www.uidaho.edu/student_orgs/arthurian_legend/grail/fisher/|date=April 1999|accessdate=23 January 2007|title=The Fisher King|publisher=University of Idaho|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070210012424/http://www.uidaho.edu/student_orgs/arthurian_legend/grail/fisher/|archivedate=10 February 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
== In literature == * ''[[Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows]]'' is the seventh and final book in [[J. K. Rowling]]'s ''[[Harry Potter]]'' series. The [[Deathly Hallows (objects)|Deathly Hallows]] refer to three legendary magical objects (supposedly obtained from Death himself) mentioned in a fairy tale: the [[Elder Wand]], which possessed the ability to conquer all others in battle, the [[Magical objects in Harry Potter#Resurrection Stone|Resurrection Stone]], which could summon the souls of the deceased, and the [[Magical objects in Harry Potter#Cloak of Invisibility|Cloak of Invisibility]], which could conceal the wearer from most forms of detection and shield them from various magic spells.<ref>[[Alastor Moody]]'s magical eye and the ''homenum revelio'' spell could overcome the cloak's stealth.{{HP4}} Moreover, [[Dementor]]s used people's emotions to perceive their location, so the cloak was useless against them.{{HP3}}</ref> Together the objects were said to make their owner a "Master of Death".{{HP7}} * ''[[The Thirteen Hallows]]'' by [[Michael Scott (Irish author)|Michael Scott]] deals with the [[Thirteen Treasures of the Island of Britain|Thirteen Hallows of Britain]]. * [[Dead Beat (The Dresden Files)|''Dead Beat'' (The Dresden Files)]] introduces the Darkhallow, a necromantic Rite of Ascension, giving the one at the center of the spell the powers of a god.
==See also== * [[Hearg]] * [[Numen]] * [[Numinous]] * [[Sacrifice]] * [[Vili and Vé]]
==References== {{reflist}} * [[Walter Baetke]], ''Das Heilige im Germanischen'', Tübingen 1942.

{{Critical pedagogy}} {{Students rights sidebar}} A '''hidden curriculum''' is a side effect of schooling, "[lessons] which are learned but not openly intended"Martin, Jane. "What Should We Do with a Hidden Curriculum When We Find One?" The Hidden Curriculum and Moral Education. Ed. Giroux, Henry and David Purpel. Berkeley, California: McCutchan Publishing Corporation, 1983. 122–139. such as the transmission of norms, values, and beliefs conveyed in the classroom and the social environment.Giroux, Henry and Anthony Penna. "Social Education in the Classroom: The Dynamics of the Hidden Curriculum." The Hidden Curriculum and Moral Education. Ed. Giroux, Henry and David Purpel. Berkeley, California: McCutchan Publishing Corporation, 1983. 100–121. It should be mentioned that the breaktime is an important part of the hidden curriculum.Cf. Kaggelaris, N. - Koutsioumari, M. I. (2015), "The breaktime as part of the hidden curriculum in Public High School", ''Pedagogy theory & praxis'' 8 (2015): 76-87 [https://www.academia.edu/22694046/_%CE%A4%CE%BF_%CE%B4%CE%B9%CE%AC%CE%BB%CE%B5%CE%B9%CE%BC%CE%BC%CE%B1_%CF%89%CF%82_%CE%BC%CE%AD%CF%81%CE%BF%CF%82_%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%85_%CE%BA%CF%81%CF%85%CF%86%CE%BF%CF%8D_%CE%B1%CE%BD%CE%B1%CE%BB%CF%85%CF%84%CE%B9%CE%BA%CE%BF%CF%8D_%CF%80%CF%81%CE%BF%CE%B3%CF%81%CE%AC%CE%BC%CE%BC%CE%B1%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%82_%CF%83%CF%84%CE%BF_%CE%94%CE%B7%CE%BC%CF%8C%CF%83%CE%B9%CE%BF_%CE%93%CE%B5%CE%BD%CE%B9%CE%BA%CF%8C_%CE%9B%CF%8D%CE%BA%CE%B5%CE%B9%CE%BF_%CE%95%CF%80%CE%B9%CF%84%CF%8C%CF%80%CE%B9%CE%B1_%CE%AD%CF%81%CE%B5%CF%85%CE%BD%CE%B1_%CF%83%CF%84%CE%BF_1%CE%BF_%CE%93%CE%95%CE%9B_%CE%94%CF%81%CE%B1%CF%80%CE%B5%CF%84%CF%83%CF%8E%CE%BD%CE%B1%CF%82_%CE%BA%CE%B1%CE%B9_%CF%83%CF%84%CE%BF_3%CE%BF_%CE%93%CE%95%CE%9B_%CE%99%CE%BB%CE%AF%CE%BF%CF%85_The_breaktime_as_part_of_the_hidden_curriculum_in_Public_High_School_Pedagogy_theory_and_praxis_8_2015_76-87]. Any learning experience may teach unintended lessons. Hidden curriculum often refers to knowledge gained in primary and secondary school settings, usually with a negative connotation where the school strives for equal intellectual development (as a positive aim).Cornbleth, Catherine. "Beyond Hidden Curriculum?" Journal of Curriculum Studies. 16.1(1984): 29–36. In this sense, a hidden curriculum reinforces existing social inequalities by educating students according to their class and [[social status]]. The unequal distribution of [[cultural capital]] in a society mirrors a corresponding distribution of knowledge among its students.Apple, Michael and Nancy King. "What Do Schools Teach?" The Hidden Curriculum and Moral Education. Ed. Giroux, Henry and David Purpel. Berkeley, California: McCutchan Publishing Corporation, 1983. 82–99. == Educational history == Early workers in the field of education were influenced by the notion that the preservation of the social privileges, interests, and knowledge of one group within the population was worth the exploitation of less powerful groups. Over time this theory has become less blatant, yet its underlying tones remain a contributing factor to the issue of the hidden curriculum. Several educational theories have been developed to help give meaning and structure to the hidden curriculum and to illustrate the role that schools play in [[socialization]]. Three of these theories, as cited by [[Henry Giroux]] and Anthony Penna, are a [[Structural functionalism|structural-functional]] view of schooling, a phenomenological view related to the "new" sociology of education, and a radical critical view corresponding to the [[neo-Marxist]] analysis of the theory and practice of education. The structural-functional view focuses on how norms and values are conveyed within schools and how their necessities for the functioning of society become indisputably accepted. The phenomenological view suggests that meaning is created through situational encounters and interactions, and it implies that knowledge is somewhat objective. The radical critical view recognizes the relationship between economic and cultural reproduction and stresses the relationships among the theory, ideology, and social practice of learning. Although the first two theories have contributed to the analysis of the hidden curriculum, the radical critical view of schooling provides the most insight. Most importantly it acknowledges the perpetuated economic and social aspects of education that are clearly illustrated by the hidden curriculum. ==Aspects== Various aspects of learning contribute to the success of the hidden curriculum, including practices, procedures, rules, relationships, and structures. Many school-specific sources, some of which may be included in these aspects of learning, give rise to important elements of the hidden curriculum. These sources may include, but are not limited to, the social structures of the classroom, the teacher's exercise of authority, rules governing the relationship between teachers and students, standard learning activities, the teacher's use of language, textbooks, audio-visual aids, furnishings, architecture, disciplinary measures, timetables, tracking systems, and curricular priorities. Variations among these sources promote the disparities found when comparing the hidden curricula corresponding to various class and social statuses. "Every school is both an expression of a political situation and a teacher of politics."{{cite book|author=Great Atlantic and Pacific School Conspiracy (Group)|title=Doing your own school: a practical guide to starting and operating a community school|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1Ws2AAAAIAAJ|accessdate=26 May 2013|year=1972|publisher=Beacon Press|isbn=978-0-8070-3172-8|page=95}} While the actual material that students absorb through the hidden curriculum is of utmost importance, the personnel who convey it elicit special investigation. This particularly applies to the social and moral lessons conveyed by the hidden curriculum, for the moral characteristics and ideologies of teachers and other authority figures are translated into their lessons, albeit not necessarily with intention.Kohlberg, Lawrence. "The Moral Atmosphere of the School." The Hidden Curriculum and Moral Education. Ed. Giroux, Henry and David Purpel. Berkeley, California: McCutchan Publishing Corporation, 1983. 61–81. Yet these unintended learning experiences can result from interactions with not only instructors, but also with peers. Like interactions with authority figures, interactions amongst peers can promote moral and social ideals but also foster the exchange of information and are thus important sources of knowledge contributing to the success of the hidden curriculum. === Heteronormativity === According to Merfat Ayesh Alsubaie, the hidden curriculum of [[heteronormativity]] is the erasure of [[LGBT|LGBTQ]] identities in the curriculum through the privileging of heterosexual identities.{{Cite journal|last=Alsubaie|first=Merfat Ayesh|date=2015|title=Hidden Curriculum as One of Current Issue of Curriculum|url=https://files.eric.ed.gov/fulltext/EJ1083566.pdf|journal=Journal of Education and Practice|volume=|pages=|via=}} In a quote from Gust Yep, heteronormativity is the "presumption and assumption that all human experience is unquestionably and automatically heterosexual".{{Cite journal|last=Yep|first=Gust|date=2002|title=From homophobia and heterosexism to heteronormativity|pmid=24804596|journal=Journal of Lesbian Studies|volume=|pages=|via=}} Laws such as "[[No promo homo laws|No Promo Homo]]" that prohibit the mention of or teaching about LGBTQ identities are considered to work to reinforce the hidden curriculum of heteronormativity.{{Cite journal|last=Chesir-Teran|first=Daniel|date=2009|title=Heterosexism in high school and victimization among lesbian, gay, bisexual, and questioning students|url=|journal=Journal of Youth & Adolescence|volume=|pages=|via=}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.glsen.org/learn/policy/issues/nopromohomo|title="No Promo Homo" Laws|website=GLSEN|language=en|access-date=2018-04-23}} In addition to No Promo Homo laws, currently over half of the states in the U.S. are not legally mandated to have any [[Sex education|sexual education]]. According to Mary Preston, the lack of sexual education in schools removes LGBTQ identities from the explicit curriculum, and contributes to the hidden curriculum of heteronormativity.{{Cite journal|last=Preston|first=Mary|date=2016|title=They're just not mature right now’: teachers' complicated perceptions of gender and anti-queer bullying|url=|journal=Sex Education|volume=|pages=|via=}} When students fall outside the heterosexual norm in schools, some students and teachers have been shown to police students back in line with heteronormative expectations.{{Cite journal|last=Puchner|first=Laurel|date=2011|title=The right time and place? Middle school language arts teachers talk about not talking about sexual orientation|url=|journal=Equity and Excellence in Education|volume=|pages=|via=}} C. J. Pascoe said policing takes place through the use of bullying behaviors such as the use of words such as "fag, queer, or dyke" which are used to shame students with identities outside the norm. Pascoe said the use of LGBTQ slurs forms a "Fag Discourse." The "Fag Discourse" in schools upholds heteronormativity as sacred, works to silence LGBTQ voices and places LGBTQ identities to the hidden curriculum.{{Cite journal|last=Pascoe|first=C.J.|date=2005|title='Dude, you're a fag': Adolescent masculinity and the fag discourse|url=|journal=Sexualities|volume=|pages=|via=}} == Function == Although the hidden curriculum conveys a great deal of knowledge to its students, the inequality promoted through its disparities among classes and social statuses often invokes a negative connotation. For example, [[Pierre Bourdieu]] asserts that education-related capital must be accessible to promote academic achievement. The effectiveness of schools becomes limited when these forms of capital are unequally distributed.Gordon, Edmumd W., Beatrice L. Bridglall, and Aundra Saa Meroe. Preface. Supplemental Education: The Hidden Curriculum of High Academic Achievement. By Gordon, Edmumd W., Beatrice L. Bridglall, and Aundra Saa Meroe. Lanham, Maryland: Rowman & Littlefield Publishers, Inc., 2005. ix–x. Since the hidden curriculum is considered to be a form of education-related capital, it promotes this ineffectiveness of schools as a result of its unequal distribution. As a means of social control, the hidden curriculum promotes the acceptance of a social destiny without promoting rational and reflective consideration.Greene, Maxine. Introduction. The Hidden Curriculum and Moral Education. By Giroux, Henry and David Purpel. Berkeley, California: McCutchan Publishing Corporation, 1983. 1–5. According to Elizabeth Vallance, the functions of hidden curriculum include "the inculcation of values, political socialization, training in obedience and docility, the perpetuation of traditional class structure-functions that may be characterized generally as social control."Vallance, Elizabeth. "Hiding the Hidden Curriculum: An Interpretation of the Language of Justification in Nineteenth-Century Educational Reform." The Hidden Curriculum and Moral Education. Ed. Giroux, Henry and David Purpel. Berkeley, California: McCutchan Publishing Corporation, 1983. 9–27. Hidden curriculum can also be associated with the reinforcement of social inequality, as evidenced by the development of different relationships to capital based on the types of work and work-related activities assigned to students varying by social class.Anyon, Jean. "Social Class and the Hidden Curriculum of Work." The Hidden Curriculum and Moral Education. Ed. Giroux, Henry and David Purpel. Berkeley, California: McCutchan Publishing Corporation, 1983. 143–167. Although the hidden curriculum has negative connotations, it is not inherently negative, and the tacit factors that are involved can potentially exert a positive developmental force on students. Some educational approaches, such as [[democratic education]], actively seek to minimize, make explicit, and/ or reorient the hidden curriculum in such a way that it has a positive developmental impact on students. Similarly, in the fields of [[environmental education]] and [[education for sustainable development]], there has been some advocacy for making school environments more natural and sustainable, such that the tacit developmental forces that these physical factors exert on students can become positive factors in their development as environmental citizens.{{Cite book|title=Earth in mind: On education, environment, and the human prospect|last=Orr|first=D.|publisher=Island Press|year=2004|isbn=|location=Covelo, CA|pages=}}{{Cite book|title=Sustainable education: Re-visioning learning and change|last=Sterling|first=S.|publisher=Green Books|year=2001|isbn=|location=Devon, UK|pages=}} == Higher education and tracking == While studies on the hidden curriculum mostly focus on fundamental primary and secondary education, higher education also feels the effects of this latent knowledge. For example, gender biases become present in specific fields of study; the quality of and experiences associated with prior education become more significant; and class, gender, and race become more evident at higher levels of education.[[Eric Margolis (sociologist)|Margolis, Eric]], Michael Soldatenko, Sandra Acker, and Marina Gair. "Peekaboo: Hiding and Outing the Curriculum." The Hidden Curriculum in Higher Education. Ed. Margolis, Eric. New York: Routledge, 2001. One additional aspect of hidden curriculum that plays a major part in the development of students and their fates is [[Tracking (education)|tracking]]. This method of imposing educational and career paths upon students at young ages relies on various factors such as class and status to reinforce socioeconomic differences. Children tend to be placed on tracks guiding them towards socioeconomic occupations similar to that of their parents, without real considerations for their strengths and weaknesses. As students advance through the educational system, they follow along their tracks by completing the predetermined courses.Rosenbaum, James E. The Hidden Curriculum of High School Tracking. New York: John Wiley & Sons, 1976. For example, this is one of the main factors limiting [[social mobility]] in America today. == Literary references == [[John Dewey]] explored the hidden curriculum of education in his early 20th century works, particularly his classic, ''[[Wikisource:Democracy and Education|Democracy and Education]]''. Dewey saw patterns evolving and trends developing in public schools which lent themselves to his pro-democratic perspectives. His work was quickly rebutted by educational theorist [[George Counts]], whose 1929 book, ''[[Dare the School Build a New Social Order?]]'' challenged the presumptive nature of Dewey's works. Where Dewey (and other [[child development]] theorists including [[Jean Piaget]], [[Erik Erikson]] and [[Maria Montessori]]) hypothesized a singular path through which all young people travelled in order to become adults, Counts recognized the reactive, adaptive, and multifaceted nature of learning. This nature caused many educators to slant their perspectives, practices, and assessments of student performance in particular directions which affected their students drastically.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} Counts' examinations were expanded on by [[Charles A. Beard]], and later, [[Myles Horton]] as he created what became the [[Highlander Folk School]] in Tennessee. The phrase "hidden curriculum" was reportedly coined by Philip W. Jackson (''Life In Classrooms'', 1968). He argued that we need to understand "[[education]]" as a [[socialization]] process. Shortly after Jackson's coinage, [[MIT]]'s Benson Snyder published ''[[The Hidden Curriculum]],'' which addresses the question of why students—even or especially the most gifted—turn away from education. Snyder advocates the thesis that much of campus conflict and students' personal anxiety is caused by a mass of unstated academic and social norms, which thwart the students' ability to develop independently or think creatively. The hidden curriculum has been further explored by a number of educators. Starting with ''[[Pedagogy of the Oppressed]]'', published in 1972, through the late 1990s, Brazilian educator [[Paulo Freire]] explored various effects of presumptive teaching on students, schools, and society as a whole. Freire's explorations were in sync with those of [[John Caldwell Holt|John Holt]] and [[Ivan Illich]], each of whom were quickly identified as radical educators. Other theorists who have identified the insidious nature of hidden curricula and hidden agendas include [[Neil Postman]], [[Paul Goodman (writer)|Paul Goodman]], [[Joel Spring]], [[John Taylor Gatto]], and others. More recent definitions were given by Roland Meighan ("A Sociology of Education", 1981):
The hidden curriculum is taught by the school, not by any teacher...something is coming across to the pupils which may never be spoken in the English lesson or prayed about in assembly. They are picking-up an approach to living and an attitude to learning.
and Michael Haralambos ("Sociology: Themes and Perspectives", 1991):
The hidden curriculum consists of those things pupils learn through the experience of attending school rather than the stated educational objectives of such institutions.
Educational critics [[Henry Giroux]], [[bell hooks]], and [[Jonathan Kozol]] also have examined the effects of hidden curriculum. [[Developmental psychologist]] [[Robert Kegan]] addressed the hidden curriculum of everyday life in his 1994 book ''[[Robert Kegan#In Over Our Heads|In Over Our Heads]]'', which focused on the relation between [[cognitive development]] and the "cognitive demands" of cultural expectations. Professor of communication [[Joseph Turow]], in his 2017 book ''The Aisles Have Eyes'', used the concept to describe acculturation to massive personal [[data collection]]; he wrote:{{cite book |last=Turow |first=Joseph |authorlink=Joseph Turow |date=2017 |title=The aisles have eyes: how retailers track your shopping, strip your privacy, and define your power |location=New Haven |publisher=[[Yale University Press]] |isbn=9780300212198 |oclc=959871776}}
The very activities that dismay privacy and anti-discrimination advocates are already beginning to become everyday habits in American lives, and part of Americans' cultural routines. Retailing is at the leading edge of a new ''hidden curriculum'' for American society—teaching people what they have to give up in order to get along in the twenty-first century.

The '''{{lang|fr|Institut canadien de Québec}}''' was founded by [[Marc-Aurèle Plamondon]] on January 17, 1848, 4 years after the founding of the ''[[Institut canadien de Montréal]]''. Originally a library open to its members, it became public in 1897. The institute currently manages the public library network of [[Quebec City]].

{{italic title}} [[File:Jacob (Francisco de Zurbarán).jpg|thumb|right|200px|''Jacob'' by Zurbarán]] '''''Jacob and his twelve sons''''' is a series of thirteen paintings by Spanish artist Francisco de [[Zurbarán]].
The series of life-size portraits was painted between 1641 and 1658.<ref>Gállego, Julián; Gudiol, José (1987). ''Zurbarán''. London: Alpine Fine Arts Collection, Ltd. pp. 353–354. {{ISBN|0-88168-115-6}}.</ref> Twelve of the thirteen paintings are in [[Auckland Castle]], [[Bishop Auckland]], England, and one is in [[Grimsthorpe Castle]], [[Lincolnshire]].
The series traveled to the Americas for the first time in 2016, to be displayed at the [[Meadows Museum]] in [[Dallas, Texas]], from 17 September 2017 until 7 January 2018, and then in New York City at the [[Frick Collection]] from 31 January until 22 April 2018.<ref name=BrownFirst>{{cite news|last1=Brown|first1=Mark|title=Zurbarán masterpieces to leave UK for US for the first time|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2016/jul/31/zurbaran-masterpieces-leave-uk-united-states-first-time-auckland-castle|accessdate=31 July 2016|publisher=The Guardian|date=31 July 2016}}</ref>
==Paintings== The depiction of Jacob and his sons in epic portraits in unusual for the era. More commonly, artists, including [[Jusepe de Ribera|Ribera]] and [[Velázquez]], included these men in narrative painting of Biblical episodes.<ref name=BaticleZurbaran/> According to art historian Jeannine Baticle, a series of Jacob and his sons survives in the possession of the Orden Tercera de San Francisco in [[Lima, Peru]], which she describes as a "fairly close replica" of the Auckland Zurbarán series. An additional series, "a more distant and awkward imitation" by an imitator, is in the possession of the Academia de Bellas Artes in [[Puebla, Puebla|Puebla]], Mexico.<ref name=BaticleZurbaran/>
==History== It is not known how the paintings reached England, although some speculate that they may have been captured by English pirates while traveling from the painter's studio in [[Seville]] to a buyer in a Spanish colony in the Americas.<ref name=BaticleZurbaran>{{cite book|last1=Baticle|first1=Jeannine|title=Zurbarán|date=1987|publisher=Metropolitan Museum of Art|isbn=0870995022|page=208}}</ref>
The series is first recorded in 1722 as part of the estate of one William Chapman.<ref name=BaticleZurbaran/> It was later owned by London Banker [[James Mendez]], whose heirs sold twelve of the thirteen to [[Richard Trevor (bishop)|Richard Trevor, Bishop of Durham]] in 1756 for [[Pound sign|£]]125. <ref>[http://www.thebowesmuseum.org.uk/Collections/ResearchScholarship/SpanishSymposium.aspx www.thebowesmuseum.org.uk]</ref> Bishop Trevor, a political liberal and a backer of the [[Jewish Naturalization Act 1753]], acquired the paintings, and redesigned and reconstructed the Long Dining Room at Auckland Palace, as a public statement of his support for Jewish naturalization rights.<ref name=MuirBishopsPalace>{{cite news|last1=Appelbaum|first1=[[Diana Muir]]|title=Jacob's Sons in the Bishop's Palace|url=http://www.jewishideasdaily.com/5364/features/jacobs-sons/|accessdate=1 August 2016|publisher=[[Jewish Ideas Daily]]|date=14 November 2012}}</ref> Although the Bill was quickly repealed, the paintings still hang in the Long Dining at Auckland.<ref name=MuirBishopsPalace/>
The portrait of one of Jacob's sons, [[Benjamin]], was sold separately to the [[Peregrine Bertie, 3rd Duke of Ancaster and Kesteven]];<ref name=BaticleZurbaran/> it hangs in [[Grimsthorpe Castle]], [[Lincolnshire]].<ref name="MorrisZurbaran">{{cite news|last1=Morris|first1=Roderick|title=Master of Light Leaps From the Shadows|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/24/arts/international/master-of-light-leaps-from-the-shadows.html?_r=0|accessdate=1 August 2016|publisher=New York Times|date=23 October 2013}}</ref> Bishop Trevor commissioned [[Arthur Pond]] to produce a copy painting of "Benjamin". It hangs, with Jacob and the other eleven sons, in the Castle's Long Dining Room, which Bishop Trevor rebuilt for the purpose of displaying the pictures.<ref>{{cite news |title=London should keep its hands off the treasures of the north |publisher=[[The Guardian]] |date=2005-10-07 |url=http://arts.guardian.co.uk/features/story/0,,1586992,00.html |accessdate=2007-08-21 |first=Simon |last=Jenkins |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070824205112/http://arts.guardian.co.uk/features/story/0%2C%2C1586992%2C00.html |archivedate=24 August 2007 |deadurl=no |df= }} </ref><ref> {{cite news | title = Bid to keep castle paintings in N-E | publisher = [[The Northern Echo]] | date = 2001-05-14 | url = http://archive.thenorthernecho.co.uk/2001/5/14/171061.html | accessdate = 2007-08-21 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070929092203/http://archive.thenorthernecho.co.uk/2001/5/14/171061.html| archivedate= 29 September 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
===21st century=== In 2001 the [[Church Commissioners]] voted to sell the paintings, a decision that was revoked in 2011 following a donation of £15 million by investment manager and philanthropist [[Jonathan Ruffer]]; new arrangements placed the paintings, along with the castle, under the Auckland Castle Trust, making them available to the public after centuries during which they hung in a private home where they could be seen only by invited guests or by special arrangement with the Bishop's staff.<ref>{{cite press release | title = Church Commissioners vote to keep the Zurbaráns | publisher = [[Church of England]] | date = 2005-09-29 | url = http://www.cofe.anglican.org/news/pr7005.html | accessdate = 2009-08-30}}</ref><ref>[http://www.debretts.com/people-of-today/profile/3229/Jonathan-Garnier-RUFFER ''Jonathan Garnier Ruffer bio at Debrett's People of Today''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150426002916/http://www.debretts.com/people-of-today/profile/3229/Jonathan-Garnier-RUFFER |date=2015-04-26 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/57d38f48-6421-11e4-8ade-00144feabdc0.html www.ft.com]</ref> <ref>{{cite press release | title = Francisco Zurbarán paintings saved by £15m donation | publisher = [[BBC]] | date = 2011-03-31 | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-12913686 | accessdate = 2011-03-31}}</ref>

'''The Joshua Project''' (formerly part of '''AD2000''') is an organization seeking to highlight the ethnic groups of the world with the least followers of [[Evangelicalism|evangelical Christianity]]. The Joshua Project maintains [[Ethnic group|ethnologic]] data to support [[Christian missions]] and is based in [[Colorado Springs, Colorado|Colorado Springs]], United States. The project began in 1995 within the former [[AD2000]] and Beyond Movement. From 2001 through 2005 the Joshua Project was at different times informally connected with Caleb Project, ICTA and World Help. In 2006, the Joshua Project officially became part of the [[U.S. Center for World Mission]], now called the [[Venture Center]].<ref>[https://www.frontierventures.org/ministries/joshua-project frontierventures.org, Joshua Project]</ref>
Focusing on [[ethnic group|ethnicity]], the project maintains a database of "[[Unreached people group|unreached peoples]]" listed by country and language. As of 2010, they list 9,803 ethnic groups. These are further divided into 16,350 peoples-by-countries, counting national minorities individually for each of 236 countries, of which 6,642 are classified as "unreached peoples". Ethnic groups are organized hierarchically in 251 "People Clusters" which in turn are divided in 16 "Affinity Blocs" ([[Arab World]], [[East Asians]], [[Eurasia]]ns, [[Cushitic|Horn of Africa-Cushitic]], [[Iranian peoples|Iranian-Median]], [[Jews]], [[Latin America#Ethnic groups|Latin-Caribbean Americans]], [[Malay peoples]], [[Demographics of North America|North American peoples]], [[Pacific Islanders]], [[South Asians]], [[Southeast Asians]], [[Sub-Saharan Africans]], [[Ethnic groups in Asia#Central Asia|Tibetan / Himalayan peoples]], [[Turkic peoples]] and Unclassified). Each ethnicity is listed as speaking at least one of 6,510 languages.<ref>{{cite web|author=Joshua Project |url=http://www.joshuaproject.net/great-commission-statistics.php |title=Great Commission Statistics |publisher=Joshua Project |date= |accessdate=2010-03-11}}</ref><ref>[http://www.peoplegroups.org/Documents/26-6-joshua-project.pdf peoplegroups.org, Joshua Project]</ref><ref>[http://www.missionfrontiers.org/issue/article/joshua-project Mission Frontiers Joshua Project]</ref> __NOTOC__ <!-- no table of contents --> ==See also== *[[10/40 Window]] *[[SIL Ethnologue]]

{{essay-like|date=November 2016}} An '''Enlightened despot''' (also called '''benevolent despot''') is an [[authoritarian]] or non-[[Democracy|democratic]] leader who exercises his political power for the benefit of the people, rather than exclusively for themselves or for an elite or small portion of the people.<ref>http://www.britannica.com/topic/enlightened-despotism</ref>
Historically they were [[monarch]]s using enlightened ideas and principles in order to enhance the central government's power (thereby their own power).{{sfn|Perry|Chase|Jacob|2015|p=442}} Most were directly linked to [[the Enlightenment]] period in the [[18th century|18th]] and early [[19th century|19th centuries]].
==Characteristics== {{main article|Enlightened absolutism}} Enlightened despots were monarchs who distinguished themselves from [[despotism|despots]] (in the ordinary sense) by the way they governed; they claimed to rule for the well-being of their subjects. For example, an enlightened despot may focus government priorities on matters of public importance such as [[healthcare]], [[education]], nonviolent population control, or physical infrastructure. He or she may be committed to [[peace]]ful relations and may even allow for some democratic decision-making to exist, such as public [[referendum|referendums,]] but did not propose reforms that would undermine their sovereignty or disrupt social order. As [[John Stuart Mill]] articulated: "Despotism is a legitimate mode of government in dealing with barbarians, provided the end be their improvement."{{sfn|Mill|1989|p=13}}
Although their reigns were based upon Enlightenment principles, their beliefs about royal power were similar to those of regular despots. Enlightened despots believed that they were destined to be ruler the moment they were born.
Enlightened rulers may have played a part in the abolition of serfdom in Europe.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Disappearance of Serfdom. France. England. Italy. Germany. Spain.|url = http://www.1902encyclopedia.com/S/SLA/slavery-12.html|website = www.1902encyclopedia.com|accessdate = 2015-12-07}}</ref>
[[Joseph II, Holy Roman Emperor|Emperor Joseph II]] once said: "Everything for the people, nothing by the people".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.habsburger.net/en/chapter/joseph-ii-long-awaited-son |title=Joseph II: The long-awaited son |author=World of the Habsburgs |work=Textmode |publisher=World of the Habsburgs |accessdate=2015-10-21 |quote=‘Everything for the people, nothing by the people’ }}</ref>
Most dictatorial regimes portray themselves as enlightened and often tend to regard democratic regimes as messy, inefficient, and corrupt. Additionally, many dictators may attempt to openly spread misinformation about their enlightenment, real or assumed, in an attempt to create a [[personality cult]].
In the Spanish language the word ''[[dictablanda]]'' is sometimes used for a dictatorship that preserves some of the liberties and mechanisms of democracy.

===Enlightened despots in recent history=== Like many [[political]] classifications, the title of enlightened despot suffers from its inherent subjectivity. In recent history dictators such as [[Lee Kuan Yew]], [[Josip Broz Tito]], [[António Salazar]], [[Isaias Afwerki]], [[Park Chung-hee]], [[Chiang Kai-shek]], [[Pervez Musharraf]], [[Thomas Sankara]], and [[Muammar Gaddafi]] can be characterized as enlightened despots. In all of these cases the point of view as to just how "enlightened" or "dictatorial" they are is largely subjective.
Generally, dictators who serve in office for a very long period are more likely to be regarded as enlightened because they will often be forced to pay some attention to the public interest in order to remain in power and, more importantly, to be regarded as [[legitimacy (political)|legitimate]]. Dictators who hold office for a brief period of time or are simply members of a rotating dictatorial elite (such as those heading some [[Totalitarianism|juntas]]) may have less [[charismatic authority]] and prove to be forgettable and are therefore often easier to demonize. In the cases of dictators such as Saddam Hussein and Muammar Gaddafi their enlightened qualities became apparent only in the wake of the breakdown of state institutions and persecution of religious and ethnic minorities that followed their removal from power.<ref>[https://www.reddit.com/r/NeutralPolitics/comments/3o5p19/some_people_contend_the_middle_east_is_better_off/ Neutral Politics]</ref>

The '''London Free School''' ('''LFS''') was founded on 8 March 1966, principally by [[John Hopkins (political activist)|John "Hoppy" Hopkins]] and [[Rhaune Laslett]].
== Description ==
The London Free School was a community action adult education project inspired by American free universities (and the Victorian Jewish Free School in Spitalfields). The organisers have been described as an "anarchic temporary coalition" of the old guard [[New Left]] and [[CND]] housing activists from the [[Rachman]] days and the new [[beatnik]]/[[hippy]] generation. The former included [[George Clark (activist)|George Clark]] of the Notting Hill Community Workshop, Richard Hauser (who ran a community scheme after the [[1958 Notting Hill race riots|1958 riots]]), Rhaune and Jim Laslett-O’Brien, Bill Richardson of the Powis and Colville Residents Association, Andre and Barbara Shervington.
To varying degrees of involvement, the hippy contingent numbered John Hopkins, [[Michael X]], Courtney Tulloch (''[[International Times|IT]]''),<ref>[[Mike Phillips (writer)|Mike Phillips]], [https://www.theguardian.com/news/2006/dec/13/guardianobituaries.obituaries1 ''Guardian'' obituary - Courtney Tulloch, 13 December 2006.]</ref> Lloyd Hunter, [[Peter Jenner]] (who was just starting to manage Pink Floyd), [[Joe Boyd]] of [[Elektra Records]] and UFO, [[Andrew King (music manager)|Andrew King]], [[Michael Horovitz]], [[John Michell]], [[Julie Felix]], [[Jeff Nuttall]], Mike McInnerney ([[Tommy (album)|''Tommy'' artist]]), Graham Keen (''IT''), [[Neil Oram]] (The Warp), Dave Tomlin (''[[International Times|IT]]''), [[Felix de Mendelssohn]] (''[[Children of Albion: Poetry of the Underground in Britain|Children of Albion]]''), [[Nigel Waymouth]] of [[Granny Takes a Trip]], [[John Esam]], [[Alexander Trocchi]], the jazz writer Ron Atkins, the [[Warhol]] star [[Kate Heliczer]], [[Harvey Matusow]] (the [[McCarthyism|McCarthy witchtrials]] saboteur), [[R. D. Laing]] and "the Belsize Park shrinks", [[Emily Young]], [[Anjelica Huston]] and [[Pink Floyd]].<ref>[http://www.historytalk.org/Notting%20Hill%20History%20Timeline/timelinechap10.pdf An historical and psychogeographical report on Notting Hill] compiled by Tom Vague for HISTORYtalk.</ref>
According to Jeff Nuttall, "Ultimately the Free School did nothing but put out a local underground newsletter and organise the 2 Notting Hill Gate Festivals, which were, admittedly, models of exactly how the arts should operate – festive, friendly, audacious, a little mad and all taking place on demolition sites, in the streets, and in a magnificently institutional church hall."<ref name="Vague2012">{{cite book|author=Tom Vague|title=Getting it Straight in Notting Hill Gate: A West London Psychogeography Report|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Q2xvCwAAQBAJ&pg=PT230|date=1 October 2012|publisher=Bread and Circuses|isbn=978-1-62517-202-0|pages=230–}}</ref> Despite this opinion, the formation of "The Notting Hill Neighbourhood Service" (one of the first centres to offer drug and legal advice in London),the [[Notting Hill Carnival]], the ''[[International Times]]'' and the [[UFO Club]] all emerged from the brief life of the LFS.
Also significant was the early development of [[Pink Floyd]], who played at [[All Saints Notting Hill|All Saints Church Hall]], initially as part of The Notting Hill Fayre (Carnival), and then a series of fund-raising concerts for the LFS. These were among the earliest gigs by the band, coming between their Spontaneous Underground period at [[The Marquee]] and the start of the UFO club.<ref>"Echoes: the complete history of Pink Floyd" By Glenn Povey.</ref>

{{About|MAC Cosmetics|Computer made by [[Apple Inc.]]|Macintosh|Mac's operating system|Mac OS}} {{Infobox company| | name = MAC Cosmetics | logo = Mac-cosmetics-logo-SH.png | type = Subsidiary | parent = [[Estée Lauder Companies]]
(1998–present) | foundation = [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], [[Canada]] 1984 | location = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[United States]] | founders = Woodland Clark
| industry = [[Final good|Consumer goods]] | products = [[Cosmetics]] | website = {{url|https://www.maccosmetics.com/}} }} '''MAC Cosmetics''', stylized as '''M·A·C''', is a cosmetics manufacturer founded in [[Toronto]], Canada in 1984 by Frank Toskan and Frank Angelo. The company is headquartered in [[New York City]] and became part of the [[Estée Lauder Companies]] in 1998. MAC is an acronym for ''Make-up Art Cosmetics''. ==Background== During his time as a photographer and makeup artist, co-founder Frank Toskan realized the lack of suitable colours and textures needed to maximize performance and result of makeup for these industries. Further, he realized how limited conventional products in the cosmetic industry were to responding to the needs of the modern woman. For the first time ethnicity in makeup was addressed. Toskan began to craft a niche market in the world of makeup. Family joined forces including brother-in-law and chemist Victor Casale. The Franks created the brand that was “by makeup artists for makeup artist.” They were also were known for creating many vivid and rich colours, for every skin tone, focusing on darker skin tones.{{cite journal |last1=Benoit |first1=Andrea |title=An Advertising World Gone Completely Haywire: MAC VIVA GLAM. |journal=Advertising & Society Review |date=2014 |volume=15 |issue=1 |url=http://muse.jhu.edu/article/541385}} MAC very quickly cultivated a following in both the fashion and the retail markets, and was responsible for creating many trends. Initially sold exclusively at the BAY in Canada it quickly expanded to Henry Bendel in New York. [[Nordstrom]] department stores welcomed the brand soon after marking MAC's first foray into the mass North American retail market [[Saks Fifth Avenue|Saks]], [[Macy's]], [[Dillard's]], and [[Bloomingdale's]] rapidly followed suit as well as dozens of MAC owned stand alone stores. Unsolicited celebrity endorsement was key to MAC's success as [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]], [[Mariah Carey]], [[Princess Diana]], [[Linda Evangelista]], [[Naomi Campbell]], [[Cher]], and [[Janet Jackson]] embraced this new world of makeup art. MAC continues to be the leader in creative cosmetic innovation worldwide.{{citation needed|date=March 2017}} The company's products were originally intended for makeup professionals, but are sold directly to consumers worldwide. Frank Toskan stated that he "first manufactured makeup for models, but then the models wanted this makeup for their sisters, friends, and so on... ".{{Cite web|title = MAC, cosmétiquement correctLa marque canadienne aux grandes causes va s'implanter en France.|url = http://www.liberation.fr/economie/0101149156-mac-cosmetiquement-correctla-marque-canadienne-aux-grandes-causes-va-s-implanter-en-france|website = Libération.fr|access-date = 2016-02-20}} Today, the brand continues to work with in fashion show professionals: "From a niche brand [mainly for photo or film], MAC has become a global brand."{{Cite web|title = Résultats recherche lesechos.fr|url = http://archives.lesechos.fr/archives/2012/LesEchos/21115-102-ECH.htm|website = Les Echos.fr|access-date = 2016-02-20|language = fr-FR}} In the 1990s, the brand had over a hundred stores worldwide, earning 200 million [[French franc|francs]]. The development of the brand internationally, the opening of new points of sale, and the adaptation of product lines tailored to each continent, left little time for the founders to create new products. In 1994, the company Estée Lauder took control of 51% of shares of MAC Cosmetics and began managing the business end{{Cite news|title = Frank Angelo, 49, Cosmetics Innovator, Dies|url = https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/17/us/frank-angelo-49-cosmetics-innovator-dies.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 1997-01-17|access-date = 2016-02-20|issn = 0362-4331|first = Anne-marie|last = Schiro}} while the two founders retained creative control. In 1997, co-founder Frank Angelo died of [[cardiac arrest]] during surgery at the age of 49. At that time, MAC had a [[revenue]] of US $250 million, which doubled ten years later.{{citation needed|date=March 2017}} Estée Lauder Inc. completed the acquisition in 1998, and Frank Toskan decided to sell his remaining shares shortly thereafter before leaving the company at the end of the same year. MAC Cosmetics is named one of the top three global makeup brands, with an annual turnover of over $1 billion, and 500 independent stores, with over thirty stores in France. All stores are run by professional makeup artists.{{cite web|title = MAC Cosmetics s'offre une vitrine sur les Champs-Elysées|url = http://archives.lesechos.fr/archives/2012/LesEchos/21115-102-ECH.htm|website = lesechos.fr|access-date = 2016-02-20|language = fr-FR|first = Dominique|last = Chapuis}} MAC is an official makeup brand, used to create makeup for movie actors. The most popular products by the brand are Studio Fix Powder Foundation and Gigablack lash mascara.{{cite web|title=MAC absolute bestsellers |url=https://www.maccosmetics.com/bestsellers |date=February 2018 |publisher=MAC Cosmetics Official}} The most popular lip product by this brand is Viva Glam Lipstick,{{cite web|title=Glam Lipstick by MAC: About |url=https://glamlipstick.com/glam-lipstick-by-mac-review-swatches.html |date=March 2018 |publisher=GlamLipstick.com}} which became popular due to smooth formula and rich pigmentation. The lipstick was released in 2014. In September 2016, MAC Cosmetics launched the "MAC Selena" collection in collaboration with the estate of [[Selena|Selena Quintanilla Perez]]. A petition on Change.org proposed the idea of this collaboration to MAC Cosmetics.{{cite web|url=http://www.refinery29.com/2016/09/123386/selena-mac-collection-latina-women-importance|title=Why MAC's Selena Collection Is SO Important For Latinas|website=refinery29.com|accessdate=28 December 2017}} Selena's sister, Suzette Quintanilla, worked with MAC to create the perfect collection that really represented Selena.{{cite web|url=http://www.expressnews.com/lifestyle/article/MAC-releases-Selena-makeup-collection-this-week-9289687.php|title=MAC releases Selena makeup collection this week|website=expressnews.com|accessdate=28 December 2017}} The collection sold out within hours not only at MAC stores but also at other retailers that carried the collection such as Nordstrom, Bloomingdales, and Macy's. Fans stood in line for hours to get their hands on the collection but some did walk away empty handed.{{cite web|url=https://cronkitenews.azpbs.org/2016/11/04/latinas-behind-growth-in-cosmetic-sales-sold-out-selena-makeup-line/|title=Latinas behind growth in cosmetic sales, sold out Selena makeup line - Cronkite News|date=4 November 2016|website=azpbs.org|accessdate=28 December 2017}} Due to the high demand for this collection, MAC restocked the collection in December 2016.{{cite web|last1=Sciarretto|first1=Amy|title=Is The MAC x Selena Restock Sold Out? The Collection Is Back & As Popular As Ever|url=https://www.bustle.com/p/is-the-mac-x-selena-restock-sold-out-the-collection-is-back-as-popular-as-ever-26621|website=Bustle|accessdate=20 March 2017}} Her posthumous collaboration with MAC Cosmetics became the best-selling celebrity collection in the [[history of cosmetics|cosmetics history]].{{cite web|last1=Acciardo|first1=Kelli|title=20 Best-selling MAC Celeb Collaborations of All-time|url=https://www.bustle.com/p/20-best-selling-mac-celeb-collaborations-of-all-time-prove-beauty-lovers-cant-get-enough-of-these-limited-edition-collections-34700|website=''Bustle.com''|access-date=13 September 2017}} In May 2017, MAC Cosmetics became available for purchase online at [[Ulta Beauty]].{{cite web|last1=Low|first1=Elaine|title=Ulta Beauty Shares Break Out As Estee Lauder Pops On Earnings|url=http://www.investors.com/news/ulta-beauty-shares-break-out-as-estee-lauder-pops-on-earnings/|website=Investor's Business Daily|accessdate=8 May 2017|date=3 May 2017}} Products became available in stores in June 2017.{{cite web|last1=Shapouri|first1=Beth|title=MAC Cosmetics Is Coming to Ulta, and Now Our Wallets Are in Trouble|url=http://www.glamour.com/story/mac-cosmetics-ulta|website=Glamour|accessdate=20 March 2017|language=en}} On August 24, 2017, MAC Cosmetics announced that a collection involved with the estate of late singer [[Aaliyah]] will be made available in the summer of 2018.{{cite web|url=http://www.harpersbazaar.com/beauty/a12089766/mac-aaliyah-collection/|title=MAC Just Announced An Aaliyah Collection|date=August 24, 2017|publisher=}} The Official release date for the "MAC Aaliyah" collection will be made available on June 20 online and June 21 in stores. Along with the MAC collection, MAC and [[I-D|i-D Magazine]] has partnered up to release a short film titled "A-Z of Aaliyah" which will coincide with the launch.{{cite web|url=https://www.elle.com/beauty/makeup-skin-care/a19655890/when-does-mac-aaliyah-collection-launch/|title=Finally, We Have a Launch Date for M.A.C's Aaliyah Collection|date=April 2, 2018|publisher=}} In May 2018, [[Sephora]] announced it would be carrying MAC Cosmetics in its stores.[https://fashionmagazine.com/beauty/mac-cosmetics-sephora/ M.A.C Cosmetics and Sephora Just Announced an Iconic Partnership] Fashion Magazine, August 18, 2018. In September 2018, fans started a petition on [[Change.org]] to ask MAC Cosmetics to collaborate with the estate of the late British singer [[Amy Winehouse]] for her own make-up collection; "MAC Amy Winehouse". After seeing other late female artists [[Selena]] and [[Aaliyah]] getting their own posthumous lines, fans stated; "Amy Winehouse's image alone inspires so many looks and trends today and has had a massive impact in women, as well as the society we live in." It has been said that the proceeds would go towards the [[Amy Winehouse Foundation]]; which raises awareness and helps young vulnerable people struggling with drug/alcohol addiction, as well as mental health issues. ==MAC AIDS Fund== {{main|Mac AIDS Fund}} The MAC AIDS Fund was established in 1994 to support men, women, and children affected by [[HIV/AIDS]] globally by addressing the link between [[poverty]] and HIV/AIDS. According to MAC Cosmetics, the fund has raised over $400 million through the sale of MAC's Viva Glam Lipsticks and Lipglosses, donating 100% of the sale price to fight HIV/AIDS.https://www.maccosmetics.com.au/viva-glam-mac-aids-fund The Viva Glam product line has been a best-seller for the MAC Cosmetics brand.[[President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief]] (November 14, 2014). [http://www.pepfar.gov/press/releases/2014/234066.htm Press release: "PEPFAR and MAC AIDS Fund Partnership Will Strengthen HIV/AIDS Services for Youth"]. Retrieved 7 November 2015. MAC has collaborated with many celebrities for its Viva Glam line, on limited edition lip glosses and lipsticks to support the [[Mac AIDS Fund]]. Every year MAC selects a new spokesperson for Viva Glam. The first was drag queen RuPaul in 1994.{{cite web |title=Mac Aids Fund - Campaign History |url=http://www.macaidsfund.org |website=MAC MAF Coresite}} RuPaul’s Viva Glam lipstick was the first product MAC Cosmetics advertised.{{cite journal |last1=Benoit |first1=Andrea |title=An advertising world gone completely haywire: MAC VIVA GLAM |journal=Advertising & Society Review: Project MUSE |date=2014 |volume=15 |issue=1 |doi=10.1353/asr.2014.0007}} The tries to prevent HIV/AIDS by focusing on the connection between HIV/AIDS and gender inequality.{{cite journal |last1=Szekeres |first1=Greg |display-authors=et al |title=Leadership development and HIV/AIDS |journal=AIDS |date=2008 |volume=22 Suppl |issue=2 |pages=519–526 |url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2810248/}} == MAC Collaborations == MAC has collaborated with several personalities over the years like [[RuPaul]],{{cite web |url=https://nationalpost.com/life/fashion-beauty/hiring-rupaul-was-just-one-of-macs-bold-progressive-moves-now-frank-toskan-finally-gets-his-dues |title=Hiring RuPaul was just one of MAC’s bold, progressive moves — now, Frank Toskan finally gets his dues |work=National Post |date=October 31, 2014 |access-date=August 18, 2018}} [[Selena]],{{cite web| url=http://www.refinery29.com/2016/09/123386/selena-mac-collection-latina-women-importance |first=Arianna |last=Davis |date=September 16, 2016 |title=Why MAC's Selena Collection Is SO Important For Latinas|website=Refinery29 |accessdate=28 December 2017}} [[Nicki Minaj]],{{Cite web |url=http://www.elle.com/beauty/makeup-skin-care/news/a47559/mac-x-nicki-minaj/ |first=Julie |last=Schott |date=Aug 22, 2017 |title=Here's What Nicki Minaj's New M.A.C Lipsticks Look Like|work=ELLE|access-date=2017-08-24|language=en}} Patrick Starrr,{{Cite web |url=https://www.cosmopolitan.com/uk/beauty-hair/makeup/a13726234/mac-patrick-starrr/ |title=Patrick Starrr's MAC collection is dreamier than Ryan Reynolds |last=Capon |first=Laura |date=Nov 15, 2017 |website=Cosmopolitan|access-date=}} [[Jeremy Scott]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.temptalia.com/mac-x-jeremy-scott-collection-for-spring-2018/|title=MAC x Jeremy Scott Collection for Spring 2018|date=2018-01-04|work=Temptalia Beauty Blog: Makeup Reviews, Beauty Tips|access-date=2018-02-20|language=en-US}} and [[Sia (musician)|Sia]].{{cite web |last1=Fasanella |first1=Kaleigh |title=A M.A.C. x Sia Viva Glam Lipstick Is Coming |url=https://www.allure.com/story/mac-x-sia-collection-viva-glam-lipstick?verso=true |date=December 1, 2017 |website=Allure |publisher=Allure Magazine {{Infobox museum | name = Majorelle Garden | native_name = Jardins Majorelle | native_name_lang = French | logo = | logo_caption = | image = Le jardin des majorelle 40.JPG | caption = Majorelle Garden | coordinates = {{coord|31|38|34|N|8|00|11|W|region:MA_type:landmark|display=title}} | former_name = | established = 1923 | dissolved = | location = [[Marrakesh]], [[Morocco]] | type = [[Art museum]] [[Garden]] | key_holdings = Berber Museum, Islamic Art Museum, Musée Yves Saint Laurent | collections = [[Berbers|Berber art]], [[Islamic art]], [[Haute couture]] | collection_size = | visitors = | founder = [[Jacques Majorelle]] | executive_director = | leader_type = | leader = | director = | president = | ceo = | chairperson = | curator = | architect = | website = }} The '''Majorelle Garden''' ({{lang-fr|Jardin Majorelle}}, {{lang-ar|حديقة ماجوريل}} hadiqat mmajuril, {{lang-ber|ⵓⵔⵜⵉ ⵎⴰⵊⵓⵔⵉⵍ}} urti majuril) is a two and half acre [[botanical garden]] and artist's [[landscape garden]] in [[Marrakech]], [[Morocco]]. It was created by the French Orientalist artist, [[Jacques Majorelle]] over almost forty years, starting in 1923, and features a Cubist villa designed by the French architect, Paul Sinoir in the 1930s. The property was the residence of the artist and his wife from 1923 until their divorce in the 1950s. In the 1980s, the property was purchased by the fashion designers, [[Yves Saint-Laurent (designer)|Yves Saint-Laurent]] and [[Pierre Bergé]] who worked to restore it. Today, the garden and villa complex is open to the public. The villa houses the '''Islamic Art Museum''' of Marrakech, the '''Berber Museum''' and has recently opened the '''Musee Yves Saint Laurent.'''
==History== [[File:Majorelle Garden.jpg|thumb|Majorelle Garden's [[cactus]] collection, with Villa in the background]] The Majorelle Garden was designed by the French artist, Jacques Majorelle (1886-1962), son of the [[Art Nouveau]] ''[[ébéniste]]'' (cabinet-maker) of Nancy, [[Louis Majorelle]]. As a young aspiring painter, Jacques Majorelle was sent to Morocco in around 1917 to convalesce from a serious medical condition. After spending a short time in Casablanca, he travelled to Marrakech and like many of his contemporaries, fell in love with the vibrant colours and street life he found there. After travelling around North Africa and the Mediterranean, he eventually decided to settle permanently in Marrakech. <ref>Marcilhac, F., ''La Vie et l'Oeuvre de Jacques Majorelle: 1886-1962,'' [The Orientalists Volume 7], ARC Internationale edition, 1988, pp 11-12</ref>
In 1923, just four years after his marriage to Andrée Longueville, Majorelle purchased a four-acre plot, situated on the border of a palm grove in Marrakech and built a house in the Mooroccan style. In 1931, he commissioned the architect, Paul Sinoir, to design a Cubist villa for the property. Gradually, he purchased additional land, extending his holding by some 10 acres. In the grounds around the residence, Majorelle began planting a luxuriant garden which would become known as the ''Jardins Majorelle'' (Majorelle Garden). The garden became his life's work and he devoted himself to developing it for almost forty years.<ref>Jardin Majorelle, ''Biography- Jacques Majorelle,'' Online: http://jardinmajorelle.com/ang/jacques-majorelle-in-morocco/</ref>
The garden proved costly to run and in 1947, Majorelle opened the garden to the public with an admission fee designed to defray the cost of maintenance.<ref>"Jacques Majorelle," ''Atlas Elite Magazine International,'' 10 July 2017, p. 8</ref> At times, he sold off parcels of land to fund the growing garden. Following his divorce in the 1950s, Majorelle was forced to sell the house and land. After this, the garden was neglected and fell into disrepair. The garden and villa were rediscovered in the 1980s, by fashion designers, [[Yves Saint-Laurent (designer)|Yves Saint-Laurent]] and [[Pierre Bergé]] who set about restoring it and saving it.<ref>''Notes on Jacques Majorelle,'' 2003, https://web.archive.org/web/20081122043640/http://www.painterskeys.com/clickbacks/majorelle.asp</ref>
[[File:Marrakech Majorelle Garden 2011.jpg|thumb|An example of Majorelle Blue from the house in the garden]] During his lifetime, Majorelle earned a reputation as a celebrated Orientalist painter. Though Majorelle's watercolors are largely forgotten today, the gardens remain as his creative masterpiece. The special shade of bold cobalt blue, inspired by the coloured tiles he had seen around Marrakech and in Berber burn-houses, was used extensively in the garden and its buildings and is named after him, ''[[Majorelle Blue|bleu Majorelle]]''—Majorelle Blue.<ref name=aat>{{cite web |url=http://www.articlesandtexticles.co.uk/2006/10/25/painters-i-should-have-known-about-007-jacques-majorelle/ |title=Painters I Should Have Known About (007) Jacques Majorelle |work=Articles & Texticles |year=2007 |accessdate=28 March 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070902084956/http://www.articlesandtexticles.co.uk/2006/10/25/painters-i-should-have-known-about-007-jacques-majorelle/ |archivedate=2 September 2007 |df= }}</ref><ref name=pk>{{cite web|url=http://www.painterskeys.com/clickbacks/majorelle.asp |work=The Painter's Keys |title=Jacques Majorelle |date=18 November 2003 |accessdate=13 August 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081122043640/http://www.painterskeys.com/clickbacks/majorelle.asp |archivedate=November 22, 2008 }}</ref> Prior to his death, Majorelle patented the colour which carries his name.
==Gardens and complex== The gardens and buildings form a complex, where specific buildings are dedicated to various museums and exhibits of interest to visitors. The gardens, which cover two and half acres, are open to the public daily and house an important collection of cacti and sculpture. The villa is home to the '''[[Berbers|Berber]] Museum''' and also features a collection of Majorelle's paintings.<ref>Foundation Jardin Majorelle, ''Le Cahiers de Musee Berbere,'' [English version], 2017</ref> Majorelle's former studio workshop has become the location of the '''Islamic Art Museum of Marrakech''' which features a collection of North African textiles from Saint-Laurent's personal collection as well as ceramics and jewelry. <ref name=JM>{{cite web|title=Bienvenue au Jardin Majorelle|url=http://www.jardinmajorelle.com/|publisher=Jardin Majorelle|accessdate=28 March 2016|language=French}}</ref>
Development of the garden complex is ongoing. Profits from the gardens are used to fund new projects. In October 2017, the '''Musee Yves Saint Laurent''' was opened to the public as a tribute to the designer's legacy and his links with Marrakech. <ref>Panguang, J.C., "In Marrakesh, a New Museum Celebrates Yves Saint Laurent," ''New York Times,'' 21 August, 2017, <Online: https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/21/t-magazine/fashion/yves-saint-laurent-museum-marrakesh.html></ref> The gardens are a major tourist drawcard in Marrakech, attracting more than 700,000 visitors annually. <ref>Foundation Jardin Majorelle, Online: http://jardinmajorelle.com/ang/fondation-jardin-majorelle/</ref>
==Organisation and management== Since 2010, the property has been owned by the Foundation Pierre Bergé – Yves Saint Laurent, a French not-for-profit organisation and since 2011 has been managed by the Foundation Jardin Majorelle, a recognized non-profit organization in Marrakech.<ref>Foundation Jardin Majorelle, Online: http://jardinmajorelle.com/ang/fondation-jardin-majorelle/</ref> Pierre Bergé was the director of the Garden's Foundation until his death in September, 2017. <ref>Diderich, J., "Pierre Bergé Ties the Knot With Madison Cox," ''WWD,'' 4 May, 2017; Howell, V., "Pierre Bergé Obituary," ''The Guardian'' (UK),Online: https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2017/sep/10/pierre-berge-obituary</ref>
==Gallery== <gallery> File:Détail d'un mur, Jardin Majorelle, Marrakech.jpg File:Pot de fleur, Jardin Majorelle, Marrakech.jpg File:Majorelle Garden corner detail, Marrakech, Morocco.jpg File:Maroc Marrakech Majorelle Luc Viatour 5.jpg File:Maroc Marrakech Majorelle Luc Viatour 4.jpg File:Jardin Majorelle in Marrakesch 07.jpg File:Marrakech Majorelle Garden 315.JPG </gallery>
The garden hosts more than 15 bird species that are endemic to North Africa. It has many fountains, and a notable collection of cacti.<ref name=aat/>
==Yves Saint-Laurent== The garden was owned by [[Yves Saint-Laurent (designer)|Yves Saint-Laurent]] and [[Pierre Bergé]] between 1980 and 2008. After Yves Saint Laurent died in 2008 his ashes were scattered in the Majorelle Garden.<ref name="YSLashes">{{cite web|url=http://www.fondation-pb-ysl.net/en/History-399.html|title=Love 1936-2008|work=Fondation Pierre Bergé - Yves Saint Laurent|year=2008|accessdate=2011-10-27}}</ref>

[[File:Schädelbestattung Metzendorf-Woxdorf.jpg|thumb|The Metzendorf-Woxdorf head burial]] The '''Metzendorf-Woxdorf head of burial''' is the [[Neolithic]] [[burial]] of a single [[human]] [[skull]] that was found in 1958 in the [[Seevetal]] district of Woxdorf, in [[Harburg (district)|Harburg]], in [[Lower Saxony]]. The find is currently the only one of its kind of the Single Grave Culture ([[German Language|German]]: {{lang|de|Einzelgrabkultur}}) in [[Germany]] and is in the permanent exhibition of the [[Archäologisches Museum Hamburg|Archaeological Museum Hamburg]] in [[Harburg, Hamburg]].<ref>Topic Death, Show case no. 53.</ref><ref name="Articus">{{cite book | last1 =Articus | first1 =Rüdiger | last2 =Brandt | first2 =Jochen | last3 =Först | first3 =Elke | last4 =Krause | first4 =Yvonne | last5 =Merkel | first5 =Michael | last6 =Mertens | first6 =Kathrin | last7 =Weiss | first7 =Rainer-Maria | title =Archaeological Museum Hamburg Helms-Museum: A short guide to the Tour of the Times | series = Archaeological Museum Hamburg publication - Helms-Museum | volume =103 | edition = | year =2013 | location = Hamburg | pages =78 | isbn =978-3-931429-24-9 }}</ref>
== Discovery ==
Even before the discovery of the head burial numerous [[Feature (archaeology)|archaeological finds]] were made in the vicinity due to intensive agricultural land use. The find spot, was located at {{coord|53.408732|9.958667|type:landmark_region:DE-NI|display=inline,title}}<ref>{{cite journal | last = Wegewitz | first = Willi | title = Eine Schädelbestattung der Einzelgrabkultur | journal = Nachrichten aus Niedersachsens Urgeschichte | volume = 29 | year = 1960 | issn = 0342-1406 | pages = 7 }}</ref> on a flat hilltop between two [[Field (agriculture)|fields]] which has not been used for agriculture. The Metzendorf-Woxdorf head burial has been discovered during levelling work, while taking off [[soil]] of the hill with a [[bulldozer]] for a pipeline for the local the Metzendorf water supply association. The workers noticed broken [[ceramic]] sherds in the plained soil. They stopped their work on this site and reported their discovery to the Helms-Museum. During the following [[Excavation (archaeology)|archaeological excavation]], a large, upside stored giant beaker ([[German Language|German]]: {{lang|de|Riesenbecher}}) was uncovered in a depth of {{convert|30|cm|in}}, the vessel floor and wall was broken by the levelling work. The giant beaker was put over a foot shell ([[German Language|German]]: {{lang|de|Fußschale}}) which contains the remnains of a single human skull.<ref name="Wegewitz_1960">{{cite journal | last = Wegewitz | first = Willi | title = Eine Schädelbestattung der Einzelgrabkultur | journal = Nachrichten aus Niedersachsens Urgeschichte | volume = 29 | year = 1960 | issn = 0342-1406 | pages = 6–17 }}</ref>
== Findings == [[File:Schädelbestattung Metzendorf-Woxdorf Zeichnung.jpg|thumb|Graphic reconstruction of the burial [[in situ]]]] The foot shell was placed on three smaller stones. It was made from a greyish brown clay having a height of {{convert|105|mm|in}} and diameters of {{convert|83|mm|in}} at the stand and {{convert|207|mm|in}} at its mouth. The outside wall of the vessel is irregularly decorated with {{convert|23|mm|in}} long parallel impressions of a comb-like tool. Inside, the foot shell was filled up to a height of two-thirds with [[humus]] soil on which the skull lay. The giant beaker was placed upside down over the cup. The retracted walls below the mouth of the vessel were carefully framed with larger stones. The giant beaker consists of a brownish-gray to reddish-brown clay. It has a height of {{convert|425|mm|in}} with diameters of about {{convert|97|mm|in}} at the base and {{convert|240|mm|in}} at the mouth. Its largest diameter is {{convert|195|mm|in}} to {{convert|210|mm|in}} at a height of {{convert|265|mm|in}} from the base. The shards of the damaged vessels base could not be recovered. Below the vessels rim, the vessel is decorated with an irregular series of small triangular recesses, whose tips are directed downward. Prior to its discovery the vessel and its interior was intact but it has been damaged with the bulldozer.<ref name="Wegewitz_1960"/> The shape of the giant beaker corresponds to the Bentheim group, defined by Karl Hermann Jacob Friesen,<ref>{{citation | first = Karl Hermann | last = Jacob-Friesen | title = Einführung in Niedersachsens Urgeschichte | publisher = Lax | location = Hildesheim | year = 1959 | pages = Fig. 156, 157 | language = German}}</ref> although this vessel stands out because of its size. Wegewitz interprets the giant beaker as storage vessel. The skull has been preserved from its [[cranium]] to the [[ear bone]]s and [[nasal bone]], while the [[facial skeleton]] and [[jaw]]s were probably decomposed after the funeral. The closed air space inside the large vessel favoured the preservation of the skull as opposed to being stored in well-aerated sandy soil at the site. In the earthy filling of the foot shell a few remains of [[tooth enamel]] were found. Due to its small amount Wegewitz suspected that at the times of the funeral only the head and upper jaw were present while the [[lower jaw]] and [[cervical vertebrae]] were already lost. The skull was [[anthropology|anthropologically]] determined as most likely that of an [[adult]] [[male]]. Whether the burial was dug in a pit into the ground or settled above the ground could not be determined due to lack of soil discolouration at site. Likewise, it remains unclear whether the head burial was created in close proximity to a possibly nearby or lost full body burial.<ref name="Wegewitz_1960"/>
Due to [[Typology (archaeology)|typological]] determination of the ceramic vessels the Metzendorf-Woxdorf head burial was [[Dating methodologies in archaeology|dated]] to the [[Chalcolithic Europe|chalcolithic period]], around 2200 BCE.<ref name="Articus"/>
== Interpretation == The [[funeral]] of a single [[Human head]], separated from his [[Human body|body]] is, unique for the [[northern Germany|northern German]] Neolithic so far, it suggests cultural influences from [[Bronze Age|early Bronze Age]] [[Bohemia]], where such separate head burials in ceramic vessels with their bodies buried underneath were common at the same time.<ref name="Laux_1995">{{citation | last = Laux | first = Friedrich | authorlink = |title= Schädelbestattung aus Metzendorf-Woxdorf, Gem. Seevetal, Ldkr. Harburg | editor = Ralf Busch |type= Fund und Deutung - Alte und neue Funde aus den archäologischen Sammlungen | publisher = Hamburger Museum für Archäologie und die Geschichte Harburgs Helms-Museum | location = Hamburg-Harburg | year = 1995 | pages = 28–29 | language = German}}</ref> Likewise, giant beakers similar to the Metzendorf-Woxdorf type were widely used there.<ref name="Articus"/> Similar archaeological finds of giant beakers are known from the [[Lüchow-Dannenberg|Hannoversches Wendland]] along the river [[Elbe]] supporting the theory of cultural ties to Bohemia, but the vessels found in Wendland were always found without content, so that the use as a funeral vessel here appears unlikely.<ref name="Laux_1995"/>

The main actors are [[Nicolás Cabré]], [[Gonzalo Heredia]], [[Nicolás Vázquez]], [[Calu Rivero]], [[Agustina Cherri]], and [[Emilia Attías]]. It began as a comedy, and switched to the [[police procedural]] genre. The program did not get enough support, and was cancelled. The last program was aired on August 8, 2014.{{cite web |url= http://personajes.lanacion.com.ar/1716224-mis-amigos-de-siempre-asi-llega-a-su-fin-una-historia-sin-ton-ni-son|title= Mis amigos de siempre: así llega a su fin una historia sin ton ni son|trans-title=Mis amigos de siempre: so it ends a confusing story|author= Silvina Ajmat|language= Spanish |date= August 8, 2014|publisher= La Nación|accessdate=August 8, 2014}} ==Plot== Julián ([[Gonzalo Heredia]]), Manuel ([[Nicolás Vázquez]]), and Simón ([[Nicolás Cabré]]) are a group of friends since childhood who spent many years at a local [[sports club]]. They meet again after a decade without seeing each other, and try to save the sports club from bankruptcy. They find out that if the club wins a certain tournament, the award will provide the economic support needed to pay the club's debts. ==Production== Pol-ka had a difficult year in 2012, as most of its productions had poor ratings against ''[[Graduados]]'', the telenovela from the rival channel [[Telefe]]. Their 2013 productions had a better reception, and ''[[Solamente Vos]]'' and ''[[Farsantes]]'' got the highest ratings. ''Mis amigos de siempre'', the production for the 2014 season, includes several actors who had not worked in Argentine television for some time, such as the senior actors [[Soledad Silveyra]] and [[Osvaldo Laport]].{{cite web |url= http://personajes.lanacion.com.ar/1634581-difunden-las-primeras-imagenes-de-mis-amigos-de-siempre|title= Se viene Mis amigos de siempre: ¡mirá las primeras imágenes!|trans-title=Mis amigos de siempre is coming, see the first images!|language= Spanish|author= |date= November 1, 2013|work= |publisher= La Nación|accessdate=December 5, 2013}} The production includes similarities with ''[[Campeones de la vida]]'', an older telenovela by Pol-Ka. The plot is focused on a sports club and many characters are sportspeople. Silveyra and Laport play a couple once more. The plots try to avoid the usual cliches in the romantic couples of telenovelas. The plots are also focused on nostalgia, but not as pronounced as in ''Graduados''. The opening theme was performed by the band [[Tan Biónica]], who had also made the opening theme of ''Graduados''.{{cite web|url= http://secciones.cienradios.com.ar/radiomitre/2013/10/29/tan-bionica-hara-la-cancion-de-mis-amigos-de-siempre/|title= Tan Biónica hará la canción de "Mis amigos de siempre"|trans-title= Tan Biónica will make the song for "Mis amigos de siempre"|language= Spanish|author= |date= October 29, 2013|work= |publisher= Radio Mitre|accessdate= December 5, 2013|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20131204002735/http://secciones.cienradios.com.ar/radiomitre/2013/10/29/tan-bionica-hara-la-cancion-de-mis-amigos-de-siempre/|archivedate= December 4, 2013|df= }} ==Reception== The first episode was aired on December 3, 2013. It got 18.1 rating points.{{cite web |url= http://personajes.lanacion.com.ar/1644268-mis-amigos-de-siempre-en-busca-del-tiempo-perdido|title= Con 18,1 puntos de rating debutó Mis amigos de According to [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia]]n, [[Asturia]]n and [[Portugal|Portuguese]] [[mythology]], the '''Mouros''' are a race of supernatural beings which inhabited the lands of [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia]], [[Asturias]] and [[Portugal]] since the beginning of time. For unknown reasons they were forced to take refuge under the earth, and now they are usually seen by people in the surroundings of ''[[castro culture|castros]]'' and [[long barrow]]s. The Mouros work with gold, silver and gem stones with which they make up enormous treasures that are protected by [[cuélebre]]s.
The Mouros do not usually go out of their dwellings, except for taking food, and also in special dates like [[Midsummer]].
Galician anthropologists had formed the theory that the '''Mouros''' are the opposite character of traditional galician peasant.
The Mouros encantados some times appear as giants or warriors, and they include the legend of the [[Enchanted Moura|moura encantada]] and the legend of the ''mourinhos'' or ''maruxinhos'', a very small [[elf]] like people who live under the ground.<ref>[http://www.noticiasdevilareal.com/noticias/index.php?action=getDetalhe&id=3629 “O Tesouro dos Maruxinhos” lançado na Biblioteca Municipal de Chaves] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111001043509/http://www.noticiasdevilareal.com/noticias/index.php?action=getDetalhe&id=3629 |date=2011-10-01 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.continuitas.org/texts/morais_portugal1.pdf Portugal, mundo dos mortos e das mouras encantadas, vol. I, Lisboa, Apenas Livros, 2009]</ref><ref>[http://www.afgc.pt/portal/bibcaneiro/Ficheiro12.pdf Autores da Região “O Tesouro dos Maruxinhos”]{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==See also== *[[Mount Pindo#Mythology|Mount Pindo]]: a supposed dwelling-place of mouros.

'''Nathan Solomon Joseph''' (1834–1909) was a British philanthropist, social reformer, architect, and Jewish communal leader.<ref>http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/74454</ref>
Joseph collaborated on the design of a number of important synagogues, including the [[Garnethill Synagogue]], [[New West End Synagogue]], and [[Hampstead Synagogue]].<ref>Sharman Kadish:''Building Jerusalem: Jewish architecture in Britain'', [[Vallentine Mitchell]], 1996, p. 5</ref> He was also noted for his work in designing improved housing for the poor.<ref>The rich and the poor: Jewish philanthropy and social control in nineteenth, Mordechai Rozin, 1999, p. 183</ref>
Joseph published widely on Jewish and social reform issues. Among his books are ''Religion Natural and Revealed: A Series of Progressive Lessons for Jewish Youth,'' (1879) and ''The Persecution of the Jews in Russia,'' (1890.) He signed his published work N.S. Joseph.
